0.00.text:
Translator: Joseph Geni
Reviewer: Morton Bast

16.12.text: Having spent 18 years as a child of the state

20.37.text: in children's homes and foster care,

22.68.text: you could say that I'm an expert on the subject,

25.72.text: and in being an expert, I want to let you know that

29.28.text: being an expert does in no way make you right

37.89.text: If you're in care, legally the government is your

53.40.text: Harry Potter was a foster child.

68.19.text: Lisbeth Salander, the girl with the dragon tattoo,

79.09.text: Lyra Belacqua from Philip Pullman's "Northern Lights"

87.22.text: Roald Dahl's James from "James and the Giant Peach;"

99.76.text: the boys in Michael Morpurgo's "Friend or Foe;"

115.81.text: Cassia in "The Concubine of Shanghai" by Hong Ying;

120.02.text: Celie in Alice Walker's "The Color Purple."

123.38.text: All of these great fictional characters, all of them

127.99.text: who were hurt by their condition,

131.99.text: all of them who spawned thousands of other books

136.64.text: and other films, all of them

143.25.text: It seems that writers know that the child

148.81.text: outside of family reflects on what family truly is

155.96.text: more than what it promotes itself to be.

159.55.text: That is, they also use extraordinary skills

164.52.text: to deal with extraordinary situations on a daily basis.

169.34.text: How have we not made the connection?

172.87.text: And why have we not made the connection, between

179.10.text: between these incredible characters of popular culture

182.67.text: and religions, and the fostered, adopted or orphaned child

187.76.text: in our midst? It's not our pity that they need.

197.61.text: I know actors and film stars and millionaires and novelists

202.68.text: and top lawyers and television executives

206.18.text: and magazine editors and national journalists

208.63.text: and dustbinmen and hairdressers, all who were

211.47.text: looked after children, fostered, adopted or orphaned,

215.01.text: and many of them grow into their adult lives

217.68.text: in fear of speaking of their background, as if it may

221.95.text: somehow weaken their standing in the foreground,

226.26.text: as if it were somehow Kryptonite, as if it were a time bomb

230.30.text: strapped on the inside. Children in care,

234.35.text: who've had a life in care, deserve the right

237.48.text: to own and live the memory of their own childhood.

245.61.text: My own mother — and I should say this here —

249.62.text: she same to this country in the late '60s,

253.47.text: and she was, you know, she found herself pregnant,

257.24.text: as women did in the late '60s. You know what I mean?

261.28.text: And she sort of, she had no idea of the context

270.08.text: In the 1960s -- I should give you some context -- in the 1960s,

273.92.text: if you were pregnant and you were single,

277.27.text: you were seen as a threat to the community.

280.18.text: You were separated from your family by the state.

286.03.text: You were separated from your family and placed into

290.86.text: You were appointed a social worker.

294.00.text: The adoptive parents were lined up.

296.39.text: It was the primary purpose of the social worker, the aim,

300.47.text: to get the woman at her most vulnerable time

303.82.text: in her entire life, to sign the adoption papers.

309.17.text: So the adoption papers were signed.

311.05.text: The mother and baby's homes were often run by nuns.

317.80.text: the child was given to the adoptive parents, and the mother

323.92.text: to say that she'd been on a little break.

331.27.text: The first secret of shame for a woman

334.84.text: for being a woman, "a little break."

339.92.text: The adoption process took, like, a matter of months,

343.01.text: so it was a closed shop, you know, sealed deal,

360.60.text: the mother, the earth, and the child, the crop.

365.40.text: It's kind of easy to patronize the past,

370.06.text: to forego our responsibilities in the present.

374.96.text: What happened then is a direct reflection

378.81.text: of what is happening now. Everybody believed themselves

384.06.text: to be doing the right thing by God and by the state

388.59.text: for the big society, fast-tracking adoption.

395.48.text: So anyway, she comes here, 1967, she's pregnant,

400.67.text: and she comes from Ethiopia that was celebrating

405.75.text: its own jubilee at the time

411.22.text: and she lands months before the Enoch Powell speech,

418.46.text: She lands months before the Beatles release "The White Album,"

423.09.text: months before Martin Luther King was killed.

425.77.text: It was a summer of love if you were white.

428.22.text: If you were black, it was a summer of hate.

431.91.text: So she goes from Oxford, she's sent to the north of England

437.56.text: to a mother and baby home, and appointed a social worker.

441.92.text: It's her plan. You know, I have to say this in the Houses --

446.16.text: It's her plan to have me fostered for a short period of time

450.43.text: while she studies. But the social worker,

457.00.text: He found the foster parents, and he said to them,

461.21.text: "Treat this as an adoption. He's yours forever.

473.54.text: So they took me. I was a message, they said.

479.76.text: I was a sign from God, they said.

485.97.text: Now, for the next 11 years, all I know is that this woman,

489.39.text: this birth woman, should have her eyes scratched out

491.97.text: for not signing the adoption papers. She was an evil woman

494.98.text: too selfish to sign, so I spent those 11 years

500.81.text: I tried praying. I swear I tried praying.

503.93.text: "God, can I have a bike for Christmas?"

507.74.text: But I would always answer myself, "Yes, of course you can."

513.70.text: And then I was supposed to determine whether that

516.44.text: was the voice of God or it was the voice of the Devil.

519.97.text: And it turns out I've got the Devil inside of me.

529.74.text: So anyway, two years sort of passed,

532.63.text: and they had a child of their own,

534.41.text: and then another two years passed, and they had another child of their own,

539.17.text: and they had another child that they called an accident,

541.74.text: which I thought was an unusual name. (Laughter)

545.15.text: And I was on the cusp of, sort of, adolescence,

548.88.text: so I was starting to take biscuits from the tin without asking.

553.28.text: I was starting to stay out a little bit late, etc., etc.

557.06.text: Now, in their religiosity, in their naivete,

560.46.text: my mom and dad, which I believed them to be forever,

562.90.text: as they said they were, my mom and dad

566.17.text: conceived that I had the Devil inside of me.

572.98.text: And what -- I should say this here, because this is how

577.00.text: They sat me at a table, my foster mom, and she said to me,

580.38.text: "You don't love us, do you?" At 11 years old.

582.45.text: They've had three other children. I'm the fourth. The third was an accident.

585.96.text: And I said, "Yeah, of course I do." Because you do.

590.01.text: My foster mother asked me to go away to think about love

592.16.text: and what it is and to read the Scriptures and to come back tomorrow

595.00.text: and give my most honest and truthful answer.

597.94.text: So this was an opportunity. If they were asking me

600.78.text: whether I loved them or not, then I mustn't love them,

603.12.text: which led me to the miracle of thought that I thought they wanted me to get to.

605.99.text: "I will ask God for forgiveness and His light will shine

608.66.text: through me to them. How fantastic." This was an opportunity.

612.42.text: The theology was perfect, the timing unquestionable,

615.21.text: and the answer as honest as a sinner could get.

618.11.text: "I mustn't love you," I said to them. "But I will ask God for forgiveness."

627.70.text: Twenty-four hours later, my social worker,

630.49.text: this strange man who used to visit me every couple of months,

633.54.text: he's waiting for me in the car as I say goodbye to my parents.

636.76.text: I didn't say goodbye to anybody, not my mother, my father,

639.33.text: my sisters, my brothers, my aunts, my uncles,

644.79.text: On the way to the children's home, I started to ask myself,

651.31.text: It's not that I'd had the rug pulled from beneath me

654.46.text: as much as the entire floor had been taken away.

663.08.text: For the next four, five years,

667.46.text: I was held in four different children's homes.

672.31.text: On the third children's home, at 15,

675.59.text: I started to rebel, and what I did was,

678.76.text: I got three tins of paint, Airfix paint that you use for models,

683.09.text: and I was -- it was a big children's home, big Victorian children's home --

686.92.text: and I was in a little turret at the top of it,

688.76.text: and I poured them, red, yellow and green,

692.06.text: the colors of Africa, down the tiles.

697.10.text: You couldn't see it from the street, because the home

702.06.text: For doing this, I was incarcerated for a year

707.01.text: in an assessment center which was actually

710.00.text: a remand center. It was a virtual prison

718.62.text: By the way, years later, my social worker said

720.67.text: that I should never have been put in there.

722.13.text: I wasn't charged for anything. I hadn't done anything wrong.

724.78.text: But because I had no family to inquire about me,

729.51.text: they could do anything to me.

741.26.text: They would march me down corridors in last-size order.

747.22.text: They -- I was put in a dormitory

753.40.text: All of the staff were ex-police -- interesting --

758.74.text: The man who ran it was an ex-army officer.

762.80.text: Every time I had a visit by a person who I did not know

765.96.text: who would feed me grapes, once every three months,

771.91.text: That home was full of young boys who were on remand

780.43.text: And this was the preparation that I was being given

784.46.text: after 17 years as a child of the state.

790.51.text: I have to tell this story.

793.09.text: I have to tell it, because there was no one

795.36.text: to put two and two together.

798.32.text: I slowly became aware that I knew nobody

801.34.text: that knew me for longer than a year.

810.08.text: I'm not defining a good family from a bad family.

812.56.text: I'm just saying that you know when your birthday is

814.38.text: by virtue of the fact that somebody tells you when your birthday is,

817.04.text: a mother, a father, a sister, a brother, an aunt, an uncle,

818.98.text: a cousin, a grandparent. It matters to someone,

820.99.text: and therefore it matters to you. Understand,

823.28.text: I was 14 years old, tucked away in myself, into myself,

827.51.text: and I wasn't touched either, physically touched.

832.29.text: I'm reporting back. I'm reporting back simply to say that

840.42.text: when I left the children's home I had two things

843.63.text: that I wanted to do. One was to find my family,

847.43.text: and the other was to write poetry.

851.51.text: In the imagination I saw the endless possibility of life,

856.67.text: the endless truth, the permanent creation of reality,

862.57.text: the place where anger was an expression

869.04.text: in the search for love, a place where dysfunction

872.78.text: is a true reaction to untruth.

877.50.text: I've just got to say it to you all: I found all of my family

881.05.text: in my adult life. I spent all of my adult life finding them,

884.41.text: and I've now got a fully dysfunctional family just like everybody else.

888.43.text: But I'm reporting back to you to say quite simply

892.17.text: that you can define how strong a democracy is

897.68.text: by how its government treats its child.

902.91.text: I don't mean children. I mean the child of the state.

904.97.text: Thanks very much. It's been an honor. (Applause)
